comments.commentBody:
If he were royalty, would I refer to the actor Gould as his Elliotness?
The spoilers clue was a challenge for me and I tried nonos to balance the HOHOS. I also wanted KEY LIMES to offset KAY NINEs, but that would be for the dogs. Doug Petersen is a very good weekend puzzle maker. I look back and don't see why it took so long, but it did.

The problem is not the name, it is what it says about Apple's relationship to women.  Either there are no females with a voice in the executive suite, or there is no respect for women in the company, or both.  Bad decision to disrespect your customers.

"But I think in the future, this will replace both the phone and the laptop."

I, for one, will forever refuse to make a phone call with something that weighs 1.5 pounds.

People said that Nintendo Wii reminded them about the word children used for urination when the product was first announced, but we all quickly forgot.

The same will happen with Ipad. And I agree that this is all just free marketing for the company.

As a stockholder I thank goodness the alarmingly terrible name choice is being discussed. Apple's strategic team clearly consists of 100% men. The word "pad" means one thing and one thing only in my vocabulary, and it isn't pleasant.

In the '50s kids collected stamps, and some of the most exotic ones bore the names of the KUT postal federation: Kenya, Uganda and Tanganyika. Zanzibar was sort of a poor relation, but after 1964 the stamps became Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania. This entry was a gimme for stamp-collecting children of the '50s.

Tanganyika has been continuously inhabited by humans and their ancestors for at least 2 million years. "Out of Africa" is really "out of Tanganyika." That's pretty cool.

I decided to Google "eyeless giza" and - don't you know - the first hit was at:

wordplay.blogs.nytimes.com

This was when today's puzzle had been on-line for about 45 minutes.

As, I think you've already figured out, I couldn't do this one without help.

-- jpgaskell

jpg,

You do know that eyeless giza hit is one year and 45 minutes old, right? Still, it's a cool coincidence.

The analysts on TNT's pre-game special Thursday night, in explaining why Lee was not voted to be an all-star reserve, called the Knicks a bad team, mentioned the 50 point loss, and made other comments which accurately describe the sorry team the Knicks are.

Of all the sick cultures in pro sports, the NBA's is the sickest. That league has a greater proportion of poorly educated, poorly socialized, one-dimensional young men with a chip on their shoulder than any other. Stern may have prevented a stroll-by shooting in the locker room for now, but this issue will arise again. One thing the NBA could do, but won't, would be to return to the old norm that players must finish college eligibility in order to turn pro. This might do something to help the maturity quotient of the players, who as things stand now pretty much go straight from the playground to the pros, and bring their handguns and 'tudes with them.

OK, I followed the link noted in my previous Post and it lead to the blog for Jan 29, 2009 (exactly 1 year ago - NOT today's) where 53A: City on the Nile = GIZA. The poster ("TTA") came up with Giza after remembering Huxley's book "Eyeless in ... "

But then we both discovered Gaza was what was meant!

Oops & double oops.

-- jpgaskell

calendario span is a nice clue for the usual Spanish 101 realm of answer, but I have to take slight issue with this one as it doesn't cross with another Spanish ñ, but instead with the n of 'runin'. año is definitely a calendar span, but ano is the Spanish word for anus. Back to the libros, Alan

The news that knee surgery is being considered for Sanchez--for an injury that he first sustained while at USC and aggravated this season--opens up myriad questions about his future and the decision to draft him in the first place. Who uses a #5 pick for a QB who has already sustained a knee injury in college (all sixteen games' worth) and has worn a knee brace in games ever since? J-E-T-S, Jets, Jets, Jets!

There has got to be lots of people holding their breath awaiting the outcome of this situation....

I have to agree with this multimillion dollar failure that the NY Times writes about. The hasty need to try their best to cause a ruckus in the reservation line is just a silly mess they have made for themselves. I understand why the first kitchen line walked out before the place opened. The food, which is the main service a restaurant provides is just simply under par. I can't help but to agree with the plastic surgery comment in this review! It is very true. I also agree that a union has no place in an American Restaurant. The management of this restaurant is just a laughter as well. Take a seat at the end of the bar and watch as the management has one break down after another. It provides for great pre-theater. I believe Bruni has a palate perfect for todays pallet!

"[Gleick] said that some of the resistance to the deal had come from authors who misunderstood some of the terms of the agreement."

That's rather patronizing. I was an Authors Guild member for several years until last November, when I let my membership lapse.

The Guild is participating in creating a de jure cartel in which Google is the chief, and the publisher's association and the Authors Guild have the exclusive right to set prices. It also allows appropriation of orphan works outside the strictures and structure of what the Copyright Office fairly clearly has statutory control of.

The Guild may be acting in the best financial interests of its authors, but the settlement sweeps in far too much for me to think it's a good idea.

Google and other parties that want to have the rights to books and other material in electronic form should be required to participate in the same leveling process that the Copyright Office has been trying for years to get put in place, rather than anointing Google the winner.

As a commuter, I could use an easy access to Internet on the bus. iPad would be ideal, in fact, it is a huge improvement on the form factor for web browsing, if it could be as light as Kindle, and uses a better 3G network.

I would need a soft stand, so that I can still doze off. I'll probably wait till then before I put my $500.
A friend in Bangkok wondered if there would be iPad Thai.

I have a Kindle and I have an iTouch and I enjoy both devices for the things that they do and I'm sure I'll get an iPad eventually as well. I don't see the iPad 'killing' the Kindle since they aren't the same sort of devices and aren't in the same price point. Each will find and keep their fans, some folks will have every one, some folks will have one or none.  There is plenty of room out there for all of these devices, there is no reason to get all fanboy to the point that you hate the other electronic devices and so really, it's a pointless argument.  Blackberry phones didn't kill Nokia phones, iPhones didn't kill Blackberry phones, Android phones didn't kill the iPhone, Nexus didn't kill other phones - in short all find their niches, and all prosper to a greater or lesser extent. And we're the winners.

I think the joke took off for many of us when we saw the Apple executive board comprises 11 men and zero women. We're laughing at them. Maybe if they allowed a woman into their boys club it wouldn't be as funny.

By the way, to those of you bringing up "generational differences," tampons have been around a lot longer than you think. Do some research on toxic shock syndrome and you'll learn why pads (if not an iPad) should be in your arsenal, too.

Yes the Kindle will succeed for people who just want to read books. But how many device do we want. I want one device that allows me to surf the net, read email, watch movies and read the NY Times. Ipad you are the one for me.

I loved my Sony eReader, which came out prior to the Kindle - until I got the Kindle app on my iPhone - and the three other eBook apps available. Now the eReader stays home. I travel with my iPhone and a netbook.

I had hoped that the iPad would be light enough to carry when I sightsee - but it isn't. If the keyboard is good enough for blogging, I will probably buy iPad Version 2.0 to replace my netbook and carry my iPhone to use as a portable eReader. I bought an external battery for $20 that charges the iPhone 1.5 times.

What do I lose by not carrying the Sony eReader? The ability to format and load NY Times magazine articles that I never got around to reading - which you can't do with a Kindle - but I can do on my netbook or an iPad.
Its as costly as a laptop with less functionality and its not a replacement for a phone.  And its another monthly data plan to shell out for.  I won't be buying one.

iPad is an absolutely terrible name and I am glad that it is being spoofed left and right -  my favorite is a very popular You Tube video making the rounds now. I live right near Silicon Valley and can't believe they couldn't harness the brainpower to come up with something better. I have already chided my friends at Apple about this, to no avail. The name turns me off - and no, its' not generational - as one gal suggested in the letters forum here.

i am just learning about this ipad thing tonight when my 13 year old son came in my room mad as heck about the price  the product itself and what it had to offer customers. he feels that if he has an item that can do all of this and he does and it is much more portable with a camera and phone and a good battery than why is apple putting this out. and then he says oh mom they have just run out of ideas and are just money hungry, then he left my room. and after doing a little research myself on this ipad i see what he is talking about. anybody who buy this has got to be out of their mind. come on apple lover what you got to say about that.
Stupid subject. Get a life....
